bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, April 28, 1889

div1.p: Carter writes about his new post, as well as his family.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, April 28, 1889
div1.opener:
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798 * U. S. * 1871
U. S. Marine-Hospital Service,
DISTRICT OF THE GULF,
Port of US. Gulf Quarantine, Surgeon's Office,
April 28, 1889.
Dear Ma:
div1.p:
I don't know if I wrote Easter Sun-
day or no. Did I? I left Monday for Biloxi &
thence up the Country per rail to get a
load of Lumber - to Pearl River & that County
which I did at $9.00 per m at the mill
instead of $14.50 as I was advised. In
the $16 m, which I bought, it comes to
a good deal, Came home Thursday
& hope I have done with Biloxi, for this
season. There is still an abundance to do
here-, as the purchase of 16000 f't of lumber testifies
but after about 10 days I think I see
C1
B29
my way clear to quiet, steady work - say
15 days. Our life - all things considered, is
far less unpleasant than S.I. & indeed is not
unpleasant at all. There is much to see. Today,
to let L. sleep, I moved the children about
a mile down the Island & saw more
kinds of new birds than I ever saw in the same time
9 marsh-hens (Poules d' Eau) in one myrtle
bush: & 10 or 15, gros- bec's, (i.e. Herons). They are
good, but have nests now: No end - probably
5000, small birds some beautiful ones & a long row of Egrets, not in flocks but every
where. It is any thing but dull here. Fishing
is not going to be good, save on the outerbeach & I
am afraid of sharks there though I've seen none.
Poor little Ned got a long button hook hung in
his throat last night & broke up the family. It
did no real injury, but hurt him & might have
done much. I think it was caught behind
the palate (on the way to the nose). I was here
providentially & got it out after some little
time. Henry came to his mother, “Mamma don't you
cry, sister asked God to take that hook out &
make him all right. Don't you mind now”. She
is inclined to impose on him, but sister is a
great standby to Henry. Both of them are
fond of the baby now, who is a very good
child, the best I've been interested in, & one
of the healthiest. Plays with himself & don't
require to be be amused,

Am afraid that I will have a busy summer
at least until August, as the fever is very
bad on the Brazilian Coast- The worst ever known
C1
B29
in Rio Janeiro. It is apt however to stop
there - or at least greatly lessen in May & June
(Nov & Dec. to them). Fortunately, the “boom ” of the
Rio Plata cities, Montevideo & Buenos Ayres,
takes most of our Rio trade & we have fewer
Rio repets than formerly.However I'll get
my share of work & I fear of sickness,

One thing here better than S. I. is a smooth, hard
& flat beach, we had none there; The view is proba-
bly not so pretty as from one place there; the house
is infinitely preferable; as is the water for boating
Although the bottom is bad (mud,) & not good
for bathing, still as we can have a bath house
on the water, & I can go to the sand beach, that
makes no difference. So far as we have gone, every
thing taken together this place is very much pref
erable to S. I. L. likes it better, & so do the children.
This is a short letter, but it is to tell you that we are all
well (H. is not quite well) & more comfortable
than we have been since we left N. O to
The children say will you please
send them a young “Grindly Gog”
They had rather not have a big one
because he might not know he
was tame. We have an attic
without floor or windows where
they propose to keep him. They
think he will be very useful to
scare Maud & Nelly when they
won't go home
think as comfortable as we were there, & with less
worries,
div1.closer:
Your affec'ate Son H. R. Carter May 1st, go to S. I. to turn over some things (lumber & old
chain) to Plata Q. officer.
